title: November 2024 Shuttle Destruction in EVE Online – Uitra Explains it All
description: I’ve already done my monthly post about the MER and destruction in EVE Online, but I wanted to pull the Uitra part out because that post was long enough as it was and because I want to sum up my revised view of what is happening in Uitra. I will say that what is actually […]
author: Wilhelm Arcturus
excerpt: I’ve already done my monthly post about the MER and destruction in EVE Online, but I wanted to pull the Uitra part out because that post was long enough as it was and because I want to sum up…
text: I’ve already done my monthly post about the MER and destruction in EVE Online, but I wanted to pull the Uitra part out because that post was long enough as it was and because I want to sum up my revised view of what is happening in Uitra. EVE Online nerds harder I will say that what is actually going on, the mechanical action of what people are doing in Uitra has been pretty clear.  The MER data shows that pretty clearly, but let’s drag that out with the losses in Uitra in November. Hull  Count Sum of ISK Lost Caldari Shuttle        16,294 381.10 million Ibis        14,101 1243.80 million Minmatar Shuttle           5,507 96.63 million Gallente Shuttle           4,354 64.89 million Amarr Shuttle           2,454 63.32 million Velator              401 35.11 million Reaper              125 12.72 million Capsule                97 433.66 million Merlin                88 14.71 million Impairor                79 6.91 million Venture                18 6.07 million Gnosis                14 696.11 million Badger                12 12.87 million Heron                10 9.94 million Bantam                  8 .91 million Griffin                  8 5.09 million Condor                  5 1.28 million Kestrel                  4 1.67 million Cormorant                  3 5.32 million Catalyst                  1 1.88 million Dramiel                  1 57.49 million Imicus                  1 .23 million That is 28,609 shuttles total lost in Uitra in November.  That is not out of line for the year so far… it isn’t even a high water mark.  The system hit nearly 40K back in June. October – 28,480 September – 20,378 August – 20,298 July – 35,739 June – 39,863 May – 37,008 April – 27,446 March – 22,149 February – 26,778 January – 20,674 The November number represents more than 38% of all shuttles destroyed in all of New Eden in those 30 days.  The system stands out on the list of the top 20 systems for shuttle losses. Hull  Count  Sum of ISK Lost System Region Shuttle        28,609 605.95 million Uitra The Forge Shuttle           7,055 155.84 million Jouvulen Lonetrek Shuttle           5,582 114.77 million Kusomonmon The Citadel Shuttle           4,601 91.98 million Akiainavas Lonetrek Shuttle           1,993 44.09 million Conoban Kor-Azor Shuttle           1,970 37,108.27 million Jita The Forge Shuttle           1,523 37.92 million Malukker Heimatar Shuttle           1,472 27.63 million Trossere Sinq Laison Shuttle           1,043 7751.31 million Ahbazon Genesis Shuttle              921 17.42 million Embod Metropolis Shuttle              909 21.73 million Pasha Tash-Murkon Shuttle              814 12.55 million Couster Essence Shuttle              652 16.38 million Mora Kor-Azor Shuttle              642 18.40 million Deepari Domain Shuttle              440 10.37 million J115127 E-R00025 Shuttle              400 8.18 million Clellinon Verge Vendor Shuttle              385 5.62 million Nosodnis Tash-Murkon Shuttle              353 8.36 million Amarr Domain Shuttle              341 7.99 million New Caldari The Forge Shuttle              320 6.04 million Hadaugago Heimatar I suppose, beside Jita, where people are still moving PLEX in shuttles for reasons not well explained, the interesting system is J115127 in wormhole space.  Are they importing shuttles for that or building them there? Most of the rest of those systems, high sec systems, play host to career agents.  Only the low sec system of Ahbazon is likely to be legit shuttle kills.  The rest of it stinks of people working the system. I always suspected the “why” aspect of Uitra was its proximity to Jita, the main market hub in New Eden. Uitra located in a what passes for a nice neighborhood in New Eden As somebody pointed out, being in The Forge you can see the Jita market from Uitra, you can buy things and go fetch them pretty handily.  Jita has everything most people want. My problem in all of this was addressing the “why” of all of this… of any of this. A few people have responded with “skill point farming,” which turns out to be true, though not in the way I was approaching it. Having rolled around New Eden since 2006, my brain comes with a lot of baggage, and jargon shorthand for something back in the day sometimes changes. So, for me, stuck in the past, “skill point farming” means extracting skill points to sell injectors on the market.  But for that you do not need a seemingly endless supply of new alts, alts so common that you give them a standard name and sequential numbers to keep track of them. Must be a coincidence For skill extraction you need clones sitting in Jita with two +6 implants training a specific skill plan so they spit out 500K skill points every week.  Maybe you can boost that a bit with some of this AIR stuff, but you don’t need a lot of one day old clones.  You main clones will last forever and replacing them would be a waste. Birds of a feather and all that That is what got me off onto the suicide gank replacement cycle path… which still could be a thing.  It is no doubt easier and cheaper to biomass a -10 clone and build up a new one than to try and fix their standing. And then I received an in-game mail from somebody who, once again, said “skill point farming” but then answered some follow on questions until I was able to get my head out of the skill injector context and into the AIR Career Program frame of mind… though skill injectors can still be a part of it. The AIR Career Program lets you earn skill points by doing a specific series of tasks, totaling up to 750K skill points total. Your AIR Career Program SP Rewards When you hit those marks, those skill points, and anything else you earn, goes into your account-wide skill redemption queue, which allows any character on your account to claim the items.  I grab the ISK for tasks I inadvertently finish on whatever character is handy all the time. So if you have a main character on an account and two AIR Career Program mules, you can redeem on your main those 750K skill points per, then once they are done, biomass those characters, make new ones, and start over again. Uitra is the nexus because you can probably buy shuttles or whatever more cheaply and more easily than anywhere else in the game.  You need the five shuttles for kills on the Soldier of Fortune track and then 20 more for the required losses.  Then things like the electronic warfare can be done with a pair just sitting on the undock and so on. Just sitting on the undock There is even a guide over on the EVE University Wiki with details on how to efficiently complete the AIR Career Program with an estimated 12 hours of effort.  750K SP in that time is a pretty good rate of return.  It makes me laugh even harder at the people bitching so hard about the Daily AIR Goals giving 10K SP for doing two goal.  To make 750K SP via that route you need 2 months if you include the 225K SP reward after doing a dozen each month.  How does that even compare to the AIR Career Program path? I am told that some corps and alliances even encourage their new members to do AIR Career Program alts routine in order to skill up their mains to get them into doctrine ships more quickly. Of course, you could just extract those skill points and sell them as well.  The broader scope of skill point farming still applies.  You just have to cycle through a lot of alts, which was the bit I was stumbling over. This is one of those things that, with a main at 270 million SP and a primary alt at over 200 million SP, never really occurred to me.  I don’t have throw away alts on either of those accounts, but alts I have trained up for specific tasks. All of this must, of course, be obvious to CCP.  I mean, Uitra is the top system for kills, and has been nearly every month for the last two years.  Even I noticed it, and I can be as oblivious as anybody about such things.  It raises the question, “Why do they allow this?” It would be easy enough to stop.  At the risk of angering the players who use this, CCP could just force these skill points to auto-apply to the character who earned them on redemption, the way they do with the AIR Daily Goals. Again, some people on r/eve were extremely angry about the daily goals, but mute on the career program.  I guess I too was ignorant until now. Also, I might suggest that shuttles should be counted in the same way that corvettes are when it comes to kills.  But maybe that is a bridge too far. But CCP hasn’t stopped it, so it must provide some benefit to them.  There must be some way in which CCP sees this as good and appropriate and helping move the game forward… or they are worried that killing it will hurt them. Or maybe they don’t see it.  Who knows?  They might just think that the new user experience is simply freaking awesome because look how many people run the entire AIR Career Program!  EVE Online is a big, complex game and nobody knows everything that is going on. I mean, you’ve seen how they have managed the main economy.  You could convince me that they are as oblivious about the skill point economy as well. The final question here, for me at least, is should I keep reporting on this in my monthly destruction post?  I think the answer is yes.  I think I will give it its own section and track the career agent systems and see where people are really going to town on this.
html:
I’ve already done my monthly post about the MER and destruction in EVE Online, but I wanted to pull the Uitra part out because that post was long enough as it was and because I want to sum up my revised view of what is happening in Uitra.

EVE Online nerds harder

I will say that what is actually going on, the mechanical action of what people are doing in Uitra has been pretty clear.  The MER data shows that pretty clearly, but let’s drag that out with the losses in Uitra in November.

Hull  Count Sum of ISK Lost
Caldari Shuttle        16,294 381.10 million
Ibis        14,101 1243.80 million
Minmatar Shuttle           5,507 96.63 million
Gallente Shuttle           4,354 64.89 million
Amarr Shuttle           2,454 63.32 million
Velator              401 35.11 million
Reaper              125 12.72 million
Capsule                97 433.66 million
Merlin                88 14.71 million
Impairor                79 6.91 million
Venture                18 6.07 million
Gnosis                14 696.11 million
Badger                12 12.87 million
Heron                10 9.94 million
Bantam                  8 .91 million
Griffin                  8 5.09 million
Condor                  5 1.28 million
Kestrel                  4 1.67 million
Cormorant                  3 5.32 million
Catalyst                  1 1.88 million
Dramiel                  1 57.49 million
Imicus                  1 .23 million

That is 28,609 shuttles total lost in Uitra in November.  That is not out of line for the year so far… it isn’t even a high water mark.  The system hit nearly 40K back in June.

  • October – 28,480
  • September – 20,378
  • August – 20,298
  • July – 35,739
  • June – 39,863
  • May – 37,008
  • April – 27,446
  • March – 22,149
  • February – 26,778
  • January – 20,674

The November number represents more than 38% of all shuttles destroyed in all of New Eden in those 30 days.  The system stands out on the list of the top 20 systems for shuttle losses.

Hull  Count  Sum of ISK Lost System Region
Shuttle        28,609 605.95 million Uitra The Forge
Shuttle           7,055 155.84 million Jouvulen Lonetrek
Shuttle           5,582 114.77 million Kusomonmon The Citadel
Shuttle           4,601 91.98 million Akiainavas Lonetrek
Shuttle           1,993 44.09 million Conoban Kor-Azor
Shuttle           1,970 37,108.27 million Jita The Forge
Shuttle           1,523 37.92 million Malukker Heimatar
Shuttle           1,472 27.63 million Trossere Sinq Laison
Shuttle           1,043 7751.31 million Ahbazon Genesis
Shuttle              921 17.42 million Embod Metropolis
Shuttle              909 21.73 million Pasha Tash-Murkon
Shuttle              814 12.55 million Couster Essence
Shuttle              652 16.38 million Mora Kor-Azor
Shuttle              642 18.40 million Deepari Domain
Shuttle              440 10.37 million J115127 E-R00025
Shuttle              400 8.18 million Clellinon Verge Vendor
Shuttle              385 5.62 million Nosodnis Tash-Murkon
Shuttle              353 8.36 million Amarr Domain
Shuttle              341 7.99 million New Caldari The Forge
Shuttle              320 6.04 million Hadaugago Heimatar

I suppose, beside Jita, where people are still moving PLEX in shuttles for reasons not well explained, the interesting system is J115127 in wormhole space.  Are they importing shuttles for that or building them there?

Most of the rest of those systems, high sec systems, play host to career agents.  Only the low sec system of Ahbazon is likely to be legit shuttle kills.  The rest of it stinks of people working the system.

I always suspected the “why” aspect of Uitra was its proximity to Jita, the main market hub in New Eden.

Uitra located in a what passes for a nice neighborhood in New Eden

As somebody pointed out, being in The Forge you can see the Jita market from Uitra, you can buy things and go fetch them pretty handily.  Jita has everything most people want.

My problem in all of this was addressing the “why” of all of this… of any of this.

A few people have responded with “skill point farming,” which turns out to be true, though not in the way I was approaching it.

Having rolled around New Eden since 2006, my brain comes with a lot of baggage, and jargon shorthand for something back in the day sometimes changes.

So, for me, stuck in the past, “skill point farming” means extracting skill points to sell injectors on the market.  But for that you do not need a seemingly endless supply of new alts, alts so common that you give them a standard name and sequential numbers to keep track of them.

Must be a coincidence

For skill extraction you need clones sitting in Jita with two +6 implants training a specific skill plan so they spit out 500K skill points every week.  Maybe you can boost that a bit with some of this AIR stuff, but you don’t need a lot of one day old clones.  You main clones will last forever and replacing them would be a waste.

Birds of a feather and all that

That is what got me off onto the suicide gank replacement cycle path… which still could be a thing.  It is no doubt easier and cheaper to biomass a -10 clone and build up a new one than to try and fix their standing.

And then I received an in-game mail from somebody who, once again, said “skill point farming” but then answered some follow on questions until I was able to get my head out of the skill injector context and into the AIR Career Program frame of mind… though skill injectors can still be a part of it.

The AIR Career Program lets you earn skill points by doing a specific series of tasks, totaling up to 750K skill points total.

Your AIR Career Program SP Rewards

When you hit those marks, those skill points, and anything else you earn, goes into your account-wide skill redemption queue, which allows any character on your account to claim the items.  I grab the ISK for tasks I inadvertently finish on whatever character is handy all the time.

So if you have a main character on an account and two AIR Career Program mules, you can redeem on your main those 750K skill points per, then once they are done, biomass those characters, make new ones, and start over again.

Uitra is the nexus because you can probably buy shuttles or whatever more cheaply and more easily than anywhere else in the game.  You need the five shuttles for kills on the Soldier of Fortune track and then 20 more for the required losses.  Then things like the electronic warfare can be done with a pair just sitting on the undock and so on.

Just sitting on the undock

There is even a guide over on the EVE University Wiki with details on how to efficiently complete the AIR Career Program with an estimated 12 hours of effort.  750K SP in that time is a pretty good rate of return.  It makes me laugh even harder at the people bitching so hard about the Daily AIR Goals giving 10K SP for doing two goal.  To make 750K SP via that route you need 2 months if you include the 225K SP reward after doing a dozen each month.  How does that even compare to the AIR Career Program path?

I am told that some corps and alliances even encourage their new members to do AIR Career Program alts routine in order to skill up their mains to get them into doctrine ships more quickly.

Of course, you could just extract those skill points and sell them as well.  The broader scope of skill point farming still applies.  You just have to cycle through a lot of alts, which was the bit I was stumbling over.

This is one of those things that, with a main at 270 million SP and a primary alt at over 200 million SP, never really occurred to me.  I don’t have throw away alts on either of those accounts, but alts I have trained up for specific tasks.

All of this must, of course, be obvious to CCP.  I mean, Uitra is the top system for kills, and has been nearly every month for the last two years.  Even I noticed it, and I can be as oblivious as anybody about such things.  It raises the question, “Why do they allow this?”

It would be easy enough to stop.  At the risk of angering the players who use this, CCP could just force these skill points to auto-apply to the character who earned them on redemption, the way they do with the AIR Daily Goals.

Again, some people on r/eve were extremely angry about the daily goals, but mute on the career program.  I guess I too was ignorant until now.

Also, I might suggest that shuttles should be counted in the same way that corvettes are when it comes to kills.  But maybe that is a bridge too far.

But CCP hasn’t stopped it, so it must provide some benefit to them.  There must be some way in which CCP sees this as good and appropriate and helping move the game forward… or they are worried that killing it will hurt them.

Or maybe they don’t see it.  Who knows?  They might just think that the new user experience is simply freaking awesome because look how many people run the entire AIR Career Program!  EVE Online is a big, complex game and nobody knows everything that is going on.

I mean, you’ve seen how they have managed the main economy.  You could convince me that they are as oblivious about the skill point economy as well.

The final question here, for me at least, is should I keep reporting on this in my monthly destruction post?  I think the answer is yes.  I think I will give it its own section and track the career agent systems and see where people are really going to town on this.
